Detailed Description

Obtains an instance of the class Image and destructs it when necessary. An image obtainer does a reference-counting, hence when all image obtainers are destructed and the image obtainer has been initialized to obtain a disposable image, the image itself will get deleted too. If objects share one instance of the class image, it is strongly recommended to use an image obtainer instead of a pointer to the image itself.

Example 1: usage of the image obtainer with a static image. The image-box contains an image obtainer, which is destructed in the destructor of the image-box. In this case native_img won't destructed, because the parameter disposable of the image obtainer-constructor has been set to FALSE (= default). 

static JpegImage jpeg_img(...);
ImageBox image_box(this, ImageObtainer(&jpeg_img));
...

Example 2: usage of the image obtainer with a dynamically allocated image. The image-box contains an image obtainer, which is destructed in the destructor of the image-box. In this case the native_img will be destructed too, because the parameter disposable of the image obtainer-constructor has been set to TRUE. 

JpegImage* jpeg_img = new JpegImage(...);
if (jpeg_img != 0) {
    ImageBox image_box(this, ImageObtainer(jpeg_img, TRUE));
    ...
}

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

ImageObtainer::ImageObtainer (   ) 
 

If the default constructor is used, the parameters have to be provided by using the method Init.

ImageObtainer::ImageObtainer (  Image *  image,
BOOLEAN  disposeable = FALSE
) 
 

Parameters:
image Pointer to the image, which may be shared.
disposable If set to TRUE, the image image will get deleted automatically, when no image obtainer references this image anymore.

ImageObtainer::ImageObtainer (  const BitmapRes &  bitmap  ) 
 

param bitmap Reference to the bitmap resource which may be shared. Note that the bitmap resource will never get deleted as it is no obtainable object. Assigning a bitmap resource directly to an image obtainer has the benefit that it prevents the overhead to create an instance of the class NativeImage which wraps a bitmap resource into an image-class. As a bitmap resource is always located in the ROM and is no instance of the class Image, the method ImageObtainer::GetBitmap must be used for getting a pointer to the bitmap resource.

ImageObtainer::ImageObtainer (  const Bitmap &  bitmap  ) 
 

param bitmap Reference to the bitmap which may be shared. Note that the bitmap will never get deleted as it is no obtainable object. Assigning a bitmap directly to an image obtainer has the benefit that it prevents the overhead to create an instance of the class NativeImage which wraps a bitmap resource into an image-class. The the method ImageObtainer::GetBitmap must be used for getting a pointer to the bitmap resource.

Member Function Documentation

const BitmapRes * ImageObtainer::GetBitmap (   )  const
 

Returns a pointer to the bitmap resource which might be obtained. Note that an image obtainer usually obtains an instance of the class Image and ImageObtainer::GetBitmap() will return 0 in this case. See also the description of ImageObtainer::ImageObtainer(const BitmapRes& bitmap) for details.

XYDIM ImageObtainer::GetHeight (   )  const
 

Returns:
Height of the image/bitmap. In opposite to GetImage()->GetHeight() an obtained bitmap is respected too (see ImageObtainer::GetBitmap). 0 is returned, if not image/bitmap is obtained.

const Image * ImageObtainer::GetImage (   )  const
 

Returns a pointer to the image which is obtained.

Image * ImageObtainer::GetImage (   ) 
 

Returns a pointer to the image which is obtained.

XYDIM ImageObtainer::GetWidth (   )  const
 

Returns:
Width of the image/bitmap. In opposite to GetImage()->GetWidth() an obtained bitmap is respected too (see ImageObtainer::GetBitmap). 0 is returned, if no image/bitmap is obtained.

BOOLEAN ImageObtainer::SetProperty (  ResourceParser &  parser,
const GuiObjectFactory::PropertyId  prop_id
) 
 

Initializes the instance by reading out a resource file generated by ARAGON. This method may not be invoked by the MMI in a direct manner and might be changed in future releases.
